In a monoid $M$, an element $b \in M$ is called an inverse of a given element $a \in M$ if $ab = e = ba$. The element $b$, if it exists, is uniquely determined by $a$ and is denoted by $a^{-1}$.

A polynomial with coefficients in a field or ring is defined as a formal sum $f=\sum_{j=0}^{n} a_{j} X^{j}$, where $a_{j}$ are the coefficients. This definition emphasizes that a polynomial is identified with the sequence of its coefficients.
A commutative ring R is called an integral domain if it is nonzero and does not admit nontrivial zero divisors.

For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the product $\mathfrak{a} \cdot \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\left\{\sum_{i=1}^{<\infty} a_{i} b_{i} ; a_{i} \in \mathfrak{a}, b_{i} \in \mathfrak{b}\right\}$.

An integral domain $R$ is called a Euclidean domain if it admits a map $\delta: R-\{0\} \longrightarrow \mathbb{N}$ making possible Euclidean division in $R$ in the following sense: Given elements $f, g \in R, g \neq 0$, there are elements $q, r \in R$ such that $f=q g+r$, where $\delta(r)<\delta(g)$ or $r=0$.

A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called free or linearly independent if from an equation sum_{i in I} a_i x_i = 0 with coefficients a_i in A we can conclude that a_i = 0 for all i in I. A free system of generators will also be referred to as a basis.
A subring $T$ of a field $K$ is called a subfield if $T$ is a field itself.

A pair of fields $K \subset L$, where $K$ is a subfield of $L$, is called a field extension. $L$ is a field extending $K$ or an extension field of $K$, or simply that $L$ is a "field extension" of $K$.
An algebraic field extension $L / K$ is trivial if every element of $L$ is algebraic over $K$.
An extension $K_{r} / K$ is Galois if it is both normal and separable.

The alternating group on $\{1, \ldots, n\}$, denoted as $\mathfrak{A}_{n}$, is the set of all even permutations in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, i.e., those permutations for which $\operatorname{sgn} \pi = 1$. It forms a normal subgroup of index 2 in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$.
The codomain of a function is the set that contains all potential output values, even if some of those values are not actually produced by any input in the domain.

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A Euclidean domain (ID: 4) is a specialization of an integral domain (ID: 2) because every Euclidean domain is by definition an integral domain that additionally admits a Euclidean division algorithm.
A field extension (ID: 7) is a specialization of a subfield (ID: 6) because every field extension involves a subfield by definition, where one field is a subfield of the other.

A trivial algebraic field extension (ID: 8) is a specialization of a field extension (ID: 7) because it is a specific type of field extension where every element of the extension field is algebraic over the base field.
A Galois extension (ID: 9) is a specialization of a field extension (ID: 7) because it is a specific type of field extension that is both normal and separable.
